description: Coding theory is useful in networking, programming, system development, and other areas where computers communicate with each other.
Game theory is useful in artificial intelligence and cybernetics.

Discrete mathematics covers the mathematics of discrete events; i.e., events that involve distinct elements, finite structures of distinct elements or finite sampled versions of continuous phenomena (such as movement).
The study of graphs. Graph theory provides foundations for data structures and searching algorithms.
Mathematical logic is the study of formal logic within mathematics. Major subareas include model theory, proof theory, set theory, and recursion theory.
Theory of the integers. Number theory is commonly used in cryptography as well as a test domain in artificial intelligence.
Algorithms are typically sequential and parallel computational procedures for solving a wide range of problems.
Data structures is the organization and manipulation of data.
Artifical intelligence involves the implementation and study of systems that exhibit an autonomous intelligence or behavior of their own.

The study of automated reasoning helps produce computer programs that allow computers to reason completely, or nearly completely, automatically. Although automated reasoning is considered a sub-field of artificial intelligence, it also has connections with theoretical computer science and philosophy.

Computer vision is concerned with the theory behind artificial systems that extract information from images. The image data can take many forms, such as video sequences, views from multiple cameras, multi-dimensional data from a 3D scanner, or medical scanning devices.
Soft computing is the use of inexact solutions for otherwise extremely difficult problems.

An interdisciplinary subfield of linguistics, computer science, and artificial intelligence concerned with the interactions between computers and human language, in particular how to program computers to process and analyze large amounts of natural language data.
An interdisciplinary branch of computer science and engineering. Robotics involves the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.
Networking involves algorithms and protocols for reliably communicating data across different shared or dedicated media, often including error correction.

Computer security involves the protection of computer systems and networks from attacks by malicious actors that may result in unauthorized information disclosure, theft of, or damage to hardware, software, or data, as well as from the disruption or misdirection of the services they provide.
Cryptography is the practice and study of techniques for secure communication in the presence of adversarial behavior.
The computer architecture is the structure of a computer system made from component parts, like CPUs and memory subsystems.
Operating systems are systems for managing computer programs and providing the basis of a usable system.

Computer graphics deals with generating images and art with the aid of computers and algorithms, both for generating visual images synthetically, and for integrating or altering visual and spatial information sampled from the real world.
keywords: Computer graphics;image generation;visual and spatial information

description: Image processing involves the use of a digital computer to process information from a digital image through an algorithm.

Information visualization is the practice of designing and creating easy-to-communicate and easy-to-understand graphic or visual representation of a large amount of complex quantitative and qualitative data and information.
The theory and practice of simultaneous computation; it also involves data safety in any multitasking or multithreaded environment.

Concurrency is the ability of different parts or units of a program, algorithm, or problem to be executed out-of-order or in partial order, without affecting the outcome. This involves using multiple concurrent threads of execution, devising algorithms for solving problems on multiple processors to achieve maximal speed-up compared to sequential execution
Distributed computing uses multiple computing devices over a network to accomplish a common objective or task and thereby reducing the latency involved in single processor contributions for any task.
The set theoretic and algorithmic foundation of databases. A relational database is a database based on the relational model of data.
Structured storage is computer storage for structured data, often in the form of a distributed database.
Data mining involves the study of algorithms for searching and processing information in documents and databases; closely related to information retrieval.
The theory of compiler design, which is based on automata theory. A compiler implements a formal transformation from a high-level source program to a low-level target program.
The taxonomy of programming languages, their strength and weaknesses. Programming language pragmatics also studies various programming paradigms, such as object-oriented programming.
The design, implementation, analysis, characterization, and classification of formal languages known as programming languages.
The rigorous mathematical study of the meaning of programs.
Type theory uses a formal analysis of the types of data, and the use of these types to understand properties of programs â€” especially program safety.
Computational science involves constructing mathematical models and quantitative analysis techniques and using computers to analyze and solve scientific problems.

Numerical analysis studies the approximate numerical solution of mathematical problems such as root-finding, integration, the solution of ordinary differential equations; the approximation of special functions.
The manipulation and solution of expressions in symbolic form, also known as Computer algebra.
Computational physics studies numerical simulations of large non-analytic systems.
Computational chemistry uses computational modelling of theoretical chemistry in order to determine chemical structures and properties

Bioinformatics and computational biology uses computer science to maintain, analyse, and store biological data and to assist in solving biological problems such as protein folding, function prediction and phylogeny.
Computational neuroscience uses computational modelling in the study of neurophysiology.
Formal methods are mathematical approaches for describing and reasoning about software design.
Software engineering describes the principles and practice of designing, developing, and testing programs, as well as proper engineering practices.
Algorithm design involves using ideas from algorithm theory to creatively design solutions to real tasks.

Computer programming is the practice of using a programming language to implement algorithms. It is also the process of performing particular computations (or more generally, accomplishing specific computing results), usually by designing and building executable computer programs and often involves tasks such as analysis, generating algorithms, profiling algorithms' accuracy and resource consumption, and the implementation of algorithms.
Human-computer interaction studies the design and the use of computer technology, which focuses on the interfaces between people and computers.
keywords: Human-computer interaction;User experience design;UX design;UI;User interaction

description: The application of the scientific method to the understanding of arbitrary existing software. Reverse engineering is a process or method through which one attempts to understand through deductive reasoning how a previously made device, process, system, or piece of software accomplishes a task with very little (if any) insight into exactly how it does so.
Automata theory is the study of abstract machines and automata, as well as the computational problems that can be solved using them. It is a theory in theoretical computer science.

Computability theory describes what is calculable with the current models of computers. Proofs developed by Alan Turing and others provide insight into the possibilities of what may be computed and what may not.
Computational complexity theory focuses on classifying computational problems according to their resource usage, and relating these classes to each other.
Quantum computing theory explores computational models involving the quantum superposition of bits.
